duty.reasoning: Complaint alleges Defendant owns the building and had responsibility and control over maintenance of the adjacent sidewalk (¶¶6,15), and alleges a duty to lawful invitees to exercise reasonable care—facts sufficient to plead a duty in a premises-liability action.

breach.reasoning: Complaint alleges facts showing Defendant cleared only a narrow path and failed to apply salt/sand or otherwise abate the hazardous condition and failed to warn despite tenant notices and photographs (¶¶7,11,17), which adequately alleges breach of the alleged duty.

causation_but_for.reasoning: Complaint alleges that because Defendant did not apply de-icing materials the cleared path became a sheet of ice (¶¶7–8) and that Plaintiff slipped on that ice and was injured (¶10), plausibly alleging that but for Defendant’s failure to treat/warn the ice would not have caused the fall.

causation_proximate.reasoning: Slip-and-fall on untreated ice is a foreseeable consequence of failing to remove or warn about icy sidewalk conditions; the complaint also alleges tenant warnings to Defendant (¶11), supporting proximate causation (¶12,18).

damages.reasoning: Complaint alleges specific economic damages (approx. $2,500 medical expenses and $800 lost wages) and ongoing pain and suffering (¶13,19), sufficiently pleading actual damages.
